description: After reviewing mounting evidence of BCI failure and unrest, Sven Halek decides to discreetly encourage trusted local technicians to experiment with alternative governance. He shares carefully chosen portions of Halden’s hidden logs, inspiring new approaches to local scoring and rules.

Led by Sven’s tip and evidence, a coalition of residents and technicians in a former pilot district openly hacks the BCI, replacing city scoring with locally agreed transparent rules. News spreads across encrypted forums, sparking urgent Council attention.

Several neighborhoods, empowered by the first pilot’s example, establish their own systems. Some abolish scores entirely; others form grassroots councils with new codes. Public celebrations erupt, and the Council’s authority declines sharply.

The Council is paralyzed as Directorate pushes for forceful intervention while Innovators propose studying local models for future citywide reforms. Harmonists caution against escalation, fearing total loss of legitimacy.

Stenograd transforms into a mosaic of experimental micro-governments. Services are uneven, but many districts report improved morale, autonomy, and community trust, despite unpredictability and Council’s irrelevance.
